qas.question: Buddhist temples in which two cities made use of the shoen system?
Why were travelers often robbed under Fujiwara rule?

answers.text: The Fujiwara rulers failed to maintain adequate police forces

qas.question: The integration of Shinto shrines into government branches reflected a greater what?
Who always maintained adequate police forces?
What system kept the aristocrates from accumulating too much wealth?
What was integrated into Shinto shrines?
What kept travelers safe during the Heian period?

context: <a1_0><b3_0>The Fujiwara<b3_0/> rulers failed to maintain adequate <b6_0>police forces<b6_0/><a1_0/>, which left robbers free to prey on travelers. This is implicitly illustrated in novels by the terror that night travel inspired in the main characters. <b4_0>The shōen system<b4_0/> enabled the accumulation of wealth by an aristocratic elite; the economic surplus can be linked to the cultural developments of the Heian period and the "pursuit of arts". The major <b5_0>Buddhist temples<b5_0/> in <a0_0>Heian-kyō and Nara<a0_0/> also made use of the shōen. The establishment of branches rurally and integration of some Shinto shrines within these temple networks reflects a greater "<a2_0>organizational dynamism<a2_0/>".
